titles.title: Carjacking Correction Act of 1996
Carjacking Correction Act of 1996
Carjacking Correction Act of 1996
To amend title 18, United States Code, to clarify the intent of Congress with respect to the Federal carjacking prohibition.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.
Referred to the Subcommittee on Crime.
Subcommittee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Forwarded by Subcommittee to Full Committee (Amended) by Voice Vote.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported (Amended) by Voice Vote.

action.text: Mr. Livingston asked unanimous consent that the Committee on Judiciary have until 5:00 p.m. on Sept. 16 to file a report on H.R. 3676. Agreed to without objection.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 104-787.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 425.

action.text: Mr. Buyer moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

vote.text: Received in the Senate, read twice, considered, read the third time, and passed without amendment by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.

bill.summary: 9/17/1996--Passed House amended. Carjacking Correction Act of 1996 - Amends the Federal criminal code to provide that for purposes of the prohibition against taking a motor vehicle that has been transported, shipped, or received in interstate or foreign commerce from another by force and violence or by intimidation with intent to cause death or serious bodily harm, "serious bodily harm" shall include any conduct that would violate provisions of the code regarding aggravated sexual abuse or sexual abuse if it occurred in the special maritime and territorial jurisdiction of the United States.
